Subjects: Virgin Mary, songs in honour of
_description: William Dunbar, ‘Ane ballat of our lady’ — six 8-line stanzas with refrain, ‘O mater Ihesu salve Maria’

BLHar1703.First Lines: Rose Marye moste of vertue vyrgynallffresche flowre on whome the heavinlye dewe downe fell…
BLHar1703.Last Lines: …The fearfull sight of dyvylles deeare ladye dryve awayeRescue thye Servaunte sweete Mayde with all thye myghtOh Mater Iesu salue Maria
BLHar1703.Note:
Eight stanzas with 10 additional stanzas by William Forrest, c.
                    1558. In penultimate line, “of dyvylles” in right margin with insertion marked in the line after “sight”; ends “finis.”
BLHar1703.Editions:
MacCracken,  Henry Noble. 
             “New Stanzas by Dunbar.” 
             “Modern Language Notes” 
         24 (1909): 110-11: 110-11.

NLS18514.Transcription:
…O chaist [ ] of clene virgineÞat closit
                    cryst…
NLS18514.Note:
Mostly illegible, added to front flyleaf by a hand of late fifteenth to
                    sixteenth century.

Asloan.First Lines:
Ros mary most of wertewe virginaleffresche flour in quhom þe
                    hevinlie dewe dovn fell…
Asloan.Last Lines:
…Benedicta tu in MulieribusO mater Ihesu salue
                    maria
Asloan.Note:
Equivalent to pages 621-22; nineteenth-century transcription is
                    Edinburgh, University Library, Laing La.IV.27-28, item 5.
Asloan.Attributed Title: Heir followis diuers ballatis of our lady (f. 300v)

EDU205.First Lines:
Roys mary most of vertu virginallfrech flowr one quhome þe
                    hewynnis dew downe fell…
